text: hi everyone phone calls Hanna here
the Internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of the new
against all logic project 2017 to 2019
electronic music producer Nicolas Jar
he is back under the against all logic
name shortly after turning so many heads
with it putting out an hour long
collection of tracks produced from 2012
to 2017 and when this thing originally
dropped I don't know if Nick's plans for
these songs were all that grand such a
wide gap in time to be putting all of
these tracks together and at first it
wasn't widely known that Nicolas Jar who
already had an established music career
was actually against all logic is this a
realization that we all would have come
to had this collection of tracks flopped
I'm not sure mostly because Nick's
philosophy and reasoning behind this
musical offshoot is still a bit of a
mystery like many of electronic music
straits Nick tends to be a little
elusive regardless the debut recieved
heaps of deserving praise for it's moody
textured disco and soul infused house
cuts that were infinitely groovy and
replayable and even though the year this
thing dropped it got a lot of love it
was still unclear what the future of
against all logic would be but
apparently what we're doing is speeding
into another full-length record 2017 to
yes which from the title has less than
half the timespan but almost as much
material 45 minutes I was worried going
into this project though for a few
reasons one Nick dropped a raggedy
single before the release of this album
both sides I did not care for both felt
too noisy too indulgent the vocal
features barely worked just not really
good material at all and even though
against all logic is a side project of
someone with a very established career
in music you do wonder if the debut is a
fluke are we going to hit a sophomore
slump well I'm happy to report that I
think the head the nine tracks here a
vast majority of them are very enjoyable
and on top of that I think generally
this one is a bit more out there than
its predecessor house music is still
very much a corner
stone for against all logic sound but
now Nick is bringing in some more
elements of techno Industrial music the
aesthetics on this thing generally are a
bit more low fie and distorted - but
more important than the genre
categorization of these tracks is how
they sound like on the opening track
fantasy where we have these sharp and
sweet vocal samples darting around over
this distorted tribal beat it sounds
like shots of white noise hits of white
noise propelling themselves over these
ambient synth layers it's pretty obvious
without having to look deeply into it
that the vocal samples on this one are
Beyonce's jar twists and chops them in a
variety of ingenious ways some of which
remind me a bit of burial the following
track if loving you is wrong is a lot
more similar in tone to many of the cuts
off 2012 to 2017 with it's cool endless
linear groove and distant soulful vocal
samples but once again jar seems content
to bring the mixes of tracks like this
down to a slightly lower fidelity
everything seems a bit noisier
while there are touches of reverb
surrounding certain elements in this
track the whole thing seems super just
boxed in and condensed into a very small
space I also love that fat euphoric
build of sound at the very end all the
hypnotic progressions that bring us to
that point - then the song transitions
seamlessly into with an addict which
does have similar aesthetics but now
they're being applied to these bustling
IDM beats and serene synth passages the
first leg is kind of plain but the
sleepy comatose hip-hop inspired
refrains that are injected into the
second part of the song or definitely a
pick-me-up and you don't just the semi
tribal rhythmic breakdowns toward the
end are worth the wait - though I much
prefer the entrancing grooves and faint
bassy rumbles as well as industrial
glitches on the track if you can't do it
good do it hard the title is based off
of a lydia lunch sample that is worked
into the second leg of the song it's
thrown in a bit haphazardly but I will
say the way that it works into the track
does fit with how raw and
very roughly cut a lot of what's going
on here is if we think about in terms of
blades and sharpness the debut is like a
surgical knife it's a scalpel it's a
very clean cut meanwhile this is more
like just a hacksaw but you're still
doing some nice stuff with it like with
the track alarm it does in fact sound
like an alarm going off urging me and
everyone around me to rush off the
factory floor that this track was
produced on is there a flammable gas
leak is there a deadly chemical spill
did someone cut their fingers off I
don't know either way I'm rushing to the
exit and this track quickly transitions
over into the Bert to a crisp cymbals
and that throbbing bass of D FERS that's
how it's spelled I do love it but what
is this you could call it techno but I
think industrial machinery coming to a
screeching halt over hypnotic rhythms is
a more fitting description in a good way
also that apocalyptic noisy bridge that
come back of the beat after that good
edge-of-your-seat progression the
infectious grooves continue on to the
track faith as well
it's just now they're being paired with
some tight rigid synth leads and distant
ghostly vocal harmonies I also love how
Nick progressively fills this empty
space with these cycling noises that are
getting closer louder like something's
creeping up on you really playing a
mental game with a listener meanwhile
the song penny in a way does lift some
of the heavy dark atmospheres that
pervade many of the tracks here it does
sound a bit more serene it does sound a
bit more I guess uplifting in a way and
I like that change of pace even if some
of the synth layers do come off very
mushy as the track gets louder and
louder and the song you forever the
closer is a pretty cool abstract
deconstructed finish to the album
everything about it from the tones to
the rhythms feels very disjointed very
disconnected there are some vocal
samples that sound like a broken
transmission trying to fight its way
through whatever is garbling or
interrupting its passageway it is
somewhat cliche to end the record off in
such a low-key and abstract way though
what I really wanted from this track was
more length more development I feel like
ultimately it's ending fizzles out a bit
too fast
even if the ideas and textures it
presents while it is on are great
overall though I loved this album quite
a bit another great record from against
all logic I think you can put another
point up on the board for Nick on this
one the production is great the genre
fusions that were presented here that
weren't on the debut are great I like
that this one went in a slightly more
abstract direction sure it does have
less material the ending could have been
stronger there were a few tracks that I
thought were just okay but for the most
part the vast majority of the material
on this thing is fantastic and just goes
to show how consistent and creative
Nicholas jar continues to be I'm feeling
a light too decent eight on this one
transition have you given this album a
listen did you love it did you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
you're the best what should I review
next hit the like if you like please
subscribe and please don't cry hit the
bell is well over here next to my head
is another video for you to check out
hit that up or the link to subscribe to
the channel Anthony Fantana against all
logic forever
